Coresets for Vertical Federated Learning: Regularized Linear Regression and KùêæK-Means Clustering

Lingxiao Huang
Nanjing University
huanglingxiao1990@126.com
&Zhize Li‚àó
Carnegie Mellon University
zhizeli@cmu.edu
Jialin Sun‚àó
Fudan University
sunjl20@fudan.edu.cn
&Haoyu Zhao‚àó
Princeton Univeristy
haoyu@princeton.edu
Alphabetical order.
Abstract

Vertical federated learning (VFL), where data features are stored in multiple parties distributively, is an important area in machine learning. However, the communication complexity for VFL is typically very high. In this paper, we propose a unified framework by constructing coresets in a distributed fashion for communication-efficient VFL. We study two important learning tasks in the VFL setting: regularized linear regression and kùëòk-means clustering, and apply our coreset framework to both problems. We theoretically show that using coresets can drastically alleviate the communication complexity, while nearly maintain the solution quality. Numerical experiments are conducted to corroborate our theoretical findings.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL)¬†[54, 40, 44, 36, 68] is a learning framework where multiple clients/parties collaboratively train a machine learning model under the coordination of a central server without exposing their raw data (i.e., each party‚Äôs raw data is stored locally and not transferred). There are two large categories of FL, horizontal federated learning (HFL) and vertical federated learning (VFL), based on the distribution characteristics of the data. In HFL, different parties usually hold different datasets but all datasets share the same features; while in VFL, all parties use the same dataset but different parties hold different subsets of the features (see Figure¬†1(a)).

Compared to HFL, VFL¬†[74, 50, 71] is generally harder and requires more communication: as a single party cannot observe the full features, it requires communication with other parties to compute the loss and the gradient of a single data. This will result in two potential problems: (i) it may require a huge amount of communication to jointly train the machine learning model when the dataset is large; and (ii) the procedure of VFL transfers the information of local data and may cause privacy leakage. Most of the VFL literature focus on the privacy issue, and designing secure training procedure for different machine learning models in the VFL setting¬†[28, 74, 72, 10]. However, the communication efficiency of the training procedure in VFL is somewhat underexplored. For unsupervised clustering problems, Ding et¬†al. [19] propose constant approximation schemes for kùëòk-means¬†clustering, and their communication complexity is linear in terms of the dataset size. For linear regression, although the communciaiton complexity can be improved to sublinear via sampling, such as SGD-type uniform sampling for the dataset¬†[50, 74], the final performance is not comparable to that using the whole dataset. Thus previous algorithms usually do not scale or perform well to the big data scenarios. 111In our numerical experiments (Section 6), we provide some results to justify this claim. This leads us to consider the following question:

How to train machine learning models using sublinear communication complexity in terms of the dataset size without sacrificing the performance in the vertical federated learning (VFL) setting?

In this paper, we try to answer this question, and our method is based on the notion of coreset¬†[27, 22, 23]. Roughly speaking, coreset can be viewed as a small data summary of the original dataset, and the machine learning model trained on the coreset performs similarly to the model trained using the full dataset. Therefore, as long as we can obtain a coreset in the VFL setting in a communication-efficient way, we can then run existing algorithms on the coreset instead of the full dataset.

Our contribution

We study the communication-efficient methods for vertical federated learning with an emphasis on scalability, and design a general paradigm through the lens of coreset. Concretely, we have the following key contributions:

  1. 1.

    We design a unified framework for coreset construction in the vertical federated learning setting (Section 3), which can help reduce the communication complexity (Theorem¬†2.5).

  2. 2.

    We study the regularized linear regression (Definition 2.1) and kùëòk-means¬†(Definition 2.2) problems in the VFL setting, and apply our unified coreset construction framework to them. We show that we can get ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-approximation for these two problems using only o‚Äã(n)ùëúùëõo(n) sublinear communications under mild conditions, where nùëõn is the size of the dataset (Section 4 and 5).

  3. 3.

    We conduct numerical experiments to validate our theoretical results. Our numerical experiments corroborate our findings that using coresets can drastically reduce the communication complexity, while maintaining the quality of the solution (Section 6). Moreover, compared to uniform sampling, applying our coresets can achieve a better solution with the same or smaller communication complexity.

1.1 More related works

Federated learning

Federated learning was introduced by McMahan et¬†al. [54], and received increasing attention in recent years. There exist many works studied in the horizontal federated learning (HFL) setting, such as algorithms with multiple local update steps¬†[54, 17, 39, 25, 56, 77] . There are also many algorithms with communication compression¬†[38, 55, 47, 45, 24, 46, 60, 21, 76, 61, 78] and algorithms with privacy preserving¬†[70, 30, 79, 64, 48].

Vertical federated learning

Due to the difficulties of VFL, people designed VFL algorithms for some particular machine learning models, including linear regression¬†[50, 74], logistic regression¬†[75, 73, 29], gradient boosting trees¬†[63, 11, 10], and kùëòk-means¬†[19]. For kùëòk-means, Ding et¬†al. [19] proposed an algorithm that computes the global centers based on the product of local centers, which requires O‚Äã(n‚ÄãT)ùëÇùëõùëáO(nT) communication complexity. For linear regression, Liu et¬†al. [50] and Yang et¬†al. [74] used uniform sampling to get unbiased gradient estimation and improved the communication efficiency, but the performance may not be good compared to that without sampling. Yang et¬†al. [73] also applied uniform sampling to quasi-Newton algorithm and improved communication complexity for logistic regression. People also studied other settings in VFL, e.g., how to align the data among different parties¬†[62], how to adopt asynchronous training¬†[9, 26], and how to defend against attacks in VFL¬†[49, 53]. In this work, we aim to develop communication-efficient algorithms to handle large-scale VFL problems.

Coreset

Coresets have been applied to a large family of problems in machine learning and statistics, including clustering¬†[22, 7, 31, 15, 16], regression¬†[20, 43, 6, 13, 34, 12], low rank approximation¬†[14], and mixture model¬†[52, 33]. Specifically, Chhaya et¬†al. [12] investigated coreset construction for regularized regression with different norms. Feldman and Langberg [22], Braverman et¬†al. [7] proposed an importance sampling framework for coreset construction for clustering (including kùëòk-means). The coreset size for kùëòk-means¬†clustering has been improved by several following works¬†[31, 15, 16] to O~‚Äã(k‚ÄãŒµ‚àí4)~ùëÇùëòsuperscriptùúÄ4\tilde{O}(k{\varepsilon}^{-4}), and Cohen-Addad et¬†al. [16] proved a lower bound of size Œ©‚Äã(Œµ‚àí2‚Äãk)Œ©superscriptùúÄ2ùëò\Omega({\varepsilon}^{-2}k). Due to the mergable property of coresets, there have been studies on coreset construction in the distributed/horizontal setting¬†[2, 58, 1, 51]. To our knowledge, we are the first to consider coreset construction in VFL.

2 Problem Formulation/Model

In this section, we formally define our problems: coresets for vertical regularized linear regression and coresets for vertical kùëòk-means¬†clustering (Problem¬†1).

Vertical federated learning model.

We first introduce the model of vertical federated learning (VFL). Let ùëø‚äÇ‚Ñùdùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} be a dataset of size nùëõn that is vertically separated stored in TùëáT data parties (T‚â•2ùëá2T\geq 2). Concretely, we represent each point ùíôi‚ààùëøsubscriptùíôùëñùëø{\bm{x}}_{i}\in{\bm{X}} by ùíôi=(ùíôi(1),‚Ä¶,ùíôi(T))subscriptùíôùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíôùëñ1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùíôùëñùëá{\bm{x}}_{i}=({\bm{x}}_{i}^{(1)},\ldots,{\bm{x}}_{i}^{(T)}) where ùíôi(j)‚àà‚Ñùdjsuperscriptsubscriptùíôùëñùëósuperscript‚Ñùsubscriptùëëùëó{\bm{x}}_{i}^{(j)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{j}} (j‚àà[T]ùëódelimited-[]ùëáj\in[T]), and each party j‚àà[T]ùëódelimited-[]ùëáj\in[T] holds a local dataset ùëø(j)={ùíôi(j)}i‚àà[n]superscriptùëøùëósubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùíôùëñùëóùëñdelimited-[]ùëõ{\bm{X}}^{(j)}=\left\{{\bm{x}}_{i}^{(j)}\right\}_{i\in[n]}. Note that ‚àëj‚àà[T]dj=dsubscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëásubscriptùëëùëóùëë\sum_{j\in[T]}d_{j}=d. Additionally, if there is a label yi‚àà‚Ñùsubscriptùë¶ùëñ‚Ñùy_{i}\in\mathbb{R} for each point ùíôi‚ààùëøsubscriptùíôùëñùëø{\bm{x}}_{i}\in{\bm{X}}, we assume the label vector ùíö‚àà‚Ñùnùíösuperscript‚Ñùùëõ{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} is stored in Party TùëáT. The objective of vertical federated learning is to collaboratively solve certain training problems in the central server with a total communication complexity as small as possible.

Similar to¬†Ding et¬†al. [19, Figure 1], we only allow the communication between the central server and each of the TùëáT parties, and require the central server to hold the final solution. Note that the central server can also be replaced with any party in practice. For the communication complexity, we assume that transporting an integer/floating-point costs 1 unit, and consequently, transporting a dùëëd-dimensional vector costs dùëëd communication units. See Figure¬†1(a) for an illustration.

Vertical regularized linear regression and vertical kùëòk-means¬†clustering.

In this paper, we consider the following two important machine learning problems in the VFL model.

Definition 2.1 (Vertical regularized linear regression (VRLR)).

Given a dataset ùëø‚äÇ‚Ñùdùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} together with labels ùíö‚àà‚Ñùnùíösuperscript‚Ñùùëõ{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} in the VFL model, a regularization function R:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùëÖ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëësubscript‚Ñùabsent0R:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, the goal of the vertical regularized linear regression problem (VRLR) is to compute a vector ùúΩ‚àà‚ÑùdùúΩsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{\theta}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} in the server that (approximately) minimizes ùñºùóàùóåùóçR‚Äã(ùëø,ùúΩ):=‚àëi‚àà[n]ùñºùóàùóåùóçiR‚Äã(ùëø,ùúΩ)=‚àëi‚àà[n](ùíôi‚ä§‚ÄãùúΩ‚àíùíöi)2+R‚Äã(ùúΩ),assignsuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùëÖùëøùúΩsubscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùëÖùëñùëøùúΩsubscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùíôùëñtopùúΩsubscriptùíöùëñ2ùëÖùúΩ\mathsf{cost}^{R}({\bm{X}},{\bm{\theta}}):=\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathsf{cost}^{R}_{i}({\bm{X}},{\bm{\theta}})=\sum_{i\in[n]}({\bm{x}}_{i}^{\top}{\bm{\theta}}-{\bm{y}}_{i})^{2}+R({\bm{\theta}}), and the total communication complexity is as small as possible.

Definition 2.2 (Vertical kùëòk-means¬†clustering (VKMC)).

Given a dataset ùëø‚äÇ‚Ñùdùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} in the VFL model, an integer k‚â•1ùëò1k\geq 1, let ùíûùíû{\mathcal{C}} denote the collection of all kùëòk-center sets ùë™‚ààùíûùë™ùíû{\bm{C}}\in{\mathcal{C}} with |ùë™|=kùë™ùëò|{\bm{C}}|=k and d‚Äã(‚ãÖ,‚ãÖ)ùëë‚ãÖ‚ãÖd(\cdot,\cdot) denote the Euclidean distance. The goal of the vertical kùëòk-means¬†clustering problem (VKMC) is to compute a kùëòk-center set ùë™‚ààùíûùë™ùíû{\bm{C}}\in{\mathcal{C}} in the server that (approximately) minimizes ùñºùóàùóåùóçC‚Äã(ùëø,ùë™):=‚àëi‚àà[n]ùñºùóàùóåùóçiC‚Äã(ùëø,ùë™)=‚àëi‚àà[n]d‚Äã(ùíôi,ùë™)2=‚àëi‚àà[n]minùíÑ‚ààùë™‚Å°d‚Äã(ùíôi,ùíÑ)2,assignsuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùê∂ùëøùë™subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùê∂ùëñùëøùë™subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõùëësuperscriptsubscriptùíôùëñùë™2subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsubscriptùíÑùë™ùëësuperscriptsubscriptùíôùëñùíÑ2\mathsf{cost}^{C}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}}):=\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathsf{cost}^{C}_{i}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}})=\sum_{i\in[n]}d({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{C}})^{2}=\sum_{i\in[n]}\min_{{\bm{c}}\in{\bm{C}}}d({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{c}})^{2}, and the total communication complexity is as small as possible.

Ding et¬†al. [19] proposed a similar vertical kùëòk-means¬†clustering problem and provided constant approximation schemes. They additionally compute an assignment from all points xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} to solution Cùê∂C, which requires a communication complexity of at least Œ©‚Äã(n‚ÄãT)Œ©ùëõùëá\Omega(nT). Due to huge nùëõn, directly solving VRLR or VKMC is a non-trivial task and may need a large communication complexity. To this end, we introduce a powerful data-reduction technique, called coresets¬†[27, 22, 23].

Coresets for VRLR and VKMC.

Roughly speaking, a coreset is a small summary of the original dataset, that approximates the learning objective for every possible choice of learning parameters. We first define coresets for offline regularized linear regression and kùëòk-means¬†clustering as follows. As mentioned in Section¬†1.1, both problems have been well studied in the literature¬†[22, 7, 12, 31, 15, 16].

Definition 2.3 (Coresets for offline regularized linear regression).

Given a dataset ùëø‚äÇ‚Ñùdùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} together with labels ùíö‚àà‚Ñùnùíösuperscript‚Ñùùëõ{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1), a subset S‚äÜ[n]ùëÜdelimited-[]ùëõS\subseteq[n] together with a weight function w:S‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùë§‚ÜíùëÜsubscript‚Ñùabsent0w:S\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} is called an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for offline regularized linear regression if for any ùúΩ‚àà‚ÑùdùúΩsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{\theta}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

Definition 2.4 (Coresets for offline kùëòk-means¬†clustering).

Given a dataset ùëø‚äÇ‚Ñùdùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, an integer k‚â•1ùëò1k\geq 1 and Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1), a subset S‚äÜ[n]ùëÜdelimited-[]ùëõS\subseteq[n] together with a weight function w:S‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùë§‚ÜíùëÜsubscript‚Ñùabsent0w:S\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} is called an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for offline kùëòk-means¬†clustering if for any kùëòk-center set ùë™‚äÇ‚Ñùdùë™superscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{C}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d},

Now we are ready to give the following main problem.

Problem 1 (Coreset construction for VRLR and VKMC).

Given a dataset ùëø‚äÇ‚Ñùdùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} (together with labels ùíö‚àà‚Ñùnùíösuperscript‚Ñùùëõ{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}) in the VFL model and Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1), our goal is to construct an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for regularized linear regression (or kùëòk-means¬†clustering) in the server, with as small communication complexity as possible. See Figure¬†1(b) for an illustration.

Note that our coreset is a subset of indices which is slightly different from that in previous work¬†[27, 22, 23], whose coreset consists of weighted points. This is because we would like to reduce data transportation from parties to the server due to privacy considerations. Specifically, if the communication schemes for VRLR and VKMC do not need to make data transportation, then we can avoid data transportation by first applying our coreset construction scheme and then doing the communication schemes based on the coreset. Moreover, we have the following theorem that shows how coresets reduce the communication complexity in the VFL models, and the proof is in Section¬†C.

Theorem 2.5 (Coresets reduce the communication complexity for VRLR and VKMC).

Given Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1), suppose there exist

  1. 1.

    a communication scheme Aùê¥A that given a (weighted) dataset ùëø‚äÇ‚Ñùdùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} together with labels ùíö‚àà‚Ñùnùíösuperscript‚Ñùùëõ{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} in the VFL model, computes an Œ±ùõº\alpha-approximate solution (Œ±‚â•1ùõº1\alpha\geq 1) for VRLR (or VKMC) in the server with a communication complexity Œõ‚Äã(n)Œõùëõ\Lambda(n);

  2. 2.

    a communication scheme A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} that given a (weighted) dataset ùëø‚äÇ‚Ñùdùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} together with labels ùíö‚àà‚Ñùnùíösuperscript‚Ñùùëõ{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} in the VFL model, constructs an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for VRLR (or VKMC respecitively) of size mùëöm in the server with a communication complexity Œõ0subscriptŒõ0\Lambda_{0}.

Then there exists a communication scheme that given a (weighted) dataset ùêó‚äÇ‚Ñùdùêósuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} together with labels ùê≤‚àà‚Ñùnùê≤superscript‚Ñùùëõ{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} in the VFL model, computes an (1+3‚ÄãŒµ)‚ÄãŒ±13ùúÄùõº(1+3{\varepsilon})\alpha-approximate solution (Œ±‚â•1ùõº1\alpha\geq 1) for VRLR (or VKMC respectively) in the server with a communication complexity Œõ0+2‚Äãm‚ÄãT+Œõ‚Äã(m)subscriptŒõ02ùëöùëáŒõùëö\Lambda_{0}+2mT+\Lambda(m).

Usually, Œõ‚Äã(m)=Œ©‚Äã(m‚ÄãT)ŒõùëöŒ©ùëöùëá\Lambda(m)=\Omega(mT) and Œõ0subscriptŒõ0\Lambda_{0} is small or comparable to T‚ÄãmùëáùëöTm (see Theorems¬†4.2 and¬†5.2 for examples). Consequently, the total communication complexity by introducing coresets is dominated by Œõ‚Äã(m)Œõùëö\Lambda(m), which is much smaller compared to Œõ‚Äã(n)Œõùëõ\Lambda(n). Hence, coreset can efficiently reduce the communication complexity with a slight sacrifice on the approximate ratio.

3 A Unified Scheme for VFL Coresets via Importance Sampling

In this section, we propose a unified communication scheme (Algorithm¬†1) that will be used as a meta-algorithm for solving Problem¬†1. We assume each party j‚àà[T]ùëódelimited-[]ùëáj\in[T] holds a real number gi(j)‚â•0superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëó0g_{i}^{(j)}\geq 0 for data ùíôi(j)superscriptsubscriptùíôùëñùëó{\bm{x}}_{i}^{(j)} in Algorithm¬†1, that will be computed locally for both VRLR (Algorithm¬†2) and VKMC (Algorithm¬†3). There are three communication rounds in Algorithm¬†1. In the first round (Lines 2-4), the server knows all ‚Äúlocal total sensitivities‚Äù ùí¢(j)superscriptùí¢ùëó{\mathcal{G}}^{(j)}, takes samples of [T]delimited-[]ùëá[T] with probability proportional to ùí¢(j)superscriptùí¢ùëó{\mathcal{G}}^{(j)}, and sends ajsubscriptùëéùëóa_{j} to each party jùëój, where ajsubscriptùëéùëóa_{j} is the number of local samples of party jùëój for the second round. In the second round (Lines 5-6), each party samples a collection S(j)‚äÜ[n]superscriptùëÜùëódelimited-[]ùëõS^{(j)}\subseteq[n] of size ajsubscriptùëéùëóa_{j} with probability proportional to gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)}. The server achieves the union S=‚ãÉj‚àà[T]S(j)ùëÜsubscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëásuperscriptùëÜùëóS=\bigcup_{j\in[T]}S^{(j)}. In the third round (Lines 7-8), the goal is to compute weights w‚Äã(i)ùë§ùëñw(i) for all samples. In the end, we achieve a weighted subset (S,w)ùëÜùë§(S,w). We propose the following theorem to analyze the performance of Algorithm¬†1 and show that (S,w)ùëÜùë§(S,w) is a coreset when size mùëöm is large enough.

Theorem 3.1 (The performance of Algorithm¬†1).

Algorithm¬†1 aims to use ‚àëj‚àà[T]gi(j)subscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëó\sum_{j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)} to estimate the sensitivity of ùíôisubscriptùíôùëñ{\bm{x}}_{i}, and hence, Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta represents the maximum sensitivity gap over all points. The performance of Algorithm¬†1 mainly depends on the quality of these estimations ‚àëj‚àà[T]gi(j)subscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëó\sum_{j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)}. As both Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta and the total sum ùí¢=‚àëi‚àà[n],j‚àà[T]gi(j)ùí¢subscriptformulae-sequenceùëñdelimited-[]ùëõùëódelimited-[]ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëó{\mathcal{G}}=\sum_{i\in[n],j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)} become smaller, the required size mùëöm becomes smaller. Specifically, if both Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta and ùí¢ùí¢{\mathcal{G}} only depends on parameters k,d,Tùëòùëëùëák,d,T, the coreset size mùëöm is independent of nùëõn as expected. Combining with Theorem¬†2.5, we can heavily reduce the communication complexity for VRLR or VKMC.

Privacy issue.

We consider the privacy of the proposed scheme from two aspects: coreset construction and model training. As for the coreset construction part (Algorithm 1), the privacy leakage comes from the "sensitivity score" gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)} of the data points in different parties. To tackle this problem, we can use secure aggregation [5] to transport the sum gi=‚àëj=1Tgi(j)subscriptùëîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{T}g_{i}^{(j)} to the server without revealing the exact values of gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)}s (Line 7 of Algorithm¬†1). The server only knows (S,w)ùëÜùë§(S,w) and ùí¢(j)superscriptùí¢ùëó{\mathcal{G}}^{(j)}s. For the model training part, we can apply the secure VFL algorithms if existed, e.g., using homomorphic encryption on SAGA for regression (it is an extension from SGD to SAGA [28]).

Note that the VFL communication model in Section¬†2 is assumed to be semi-honest. Suppose some party jùëój is malicious, then it can report a large enough ùí¢(j)superscriptùí¢ùëó{\mathcal{G}}^{(j)} (Line 2 of Algorithm¬†1) such that the server sets the number of samples aj‚âàmsubscriptùëéùëóùëöa_{j}\approx m in party jùëój (Line 4 of Algorithm¬†1). Consequently, party jùëój can sample a large multi-set S(j)superscriptùëÜùëóS^{(j)} which heavily affects the resulting set SùëÜS. For instance, by reporting S(j)superscriptùëÜùëóS^{(j)} of uniform samples, party jùëój can make SùëÜS close to uniform sampling and loss the theoretical guarantees in Theorem¬†3.1.

4 Coreset Construction for VRLR

In this section, we discuss the coreset construction for VRLR. We first show that it is generally hard to construct a strong coreset for VRLR. Then, we show how to communication-efficiently construct coresets for VRLR under mild assumption. All missing proofs can be found in Section¬†E.

With slightly abuse of notation, we denote ùëø‚àà‚Ñùn√ód,ùëø(j)‚àà‚Ñùn√ódjformulae-sequenceùëøsuperscript‚Ñùùëõùëësuperscriptùëøùëósuperscript‚Ñùùëõsubscriptùëëùëó{\bm{X}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d},{\bm{X}}^{(j)}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d_{j}} to be the data matrix of whole data and the data matrix stored on party jùëój respectively. Since there are labels ùíöùíö{\bm{y}} stored on party TùëáT, ùëø(T)superscriptùëøùëá{\bm{X}}^{(T)} has dimension n√ó(dT+1)ùëõsubscriptùëëùëá1n\times(d_{T}+1).

Communication complexity lower bound for VRLR

We first show that it is hard to compute the coreset for VRLR by proving an Œ©‚Äã(n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(n) deterministic communication complexity lower bound.

Theorem 4.1 (Communication complexity of coreset construction for VRLR).

Let T‚â•2ùëá2T\geq 2. Given constant Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1), any deterministic communication scheme that constructs an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for VRLR requires a communication complexity Œ©‚Äã(n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(n).

The communication complexity lower bound for linear regression has also been considered in the HFL setting¬†[67], e.g., Vempala et¬†al. [67] also gets a deterministic communication complexity lower bound. Theorem 4.1 shows that linear regression in the VFL setting is ‚Äúhard‚Äù and thus we may need to add data assumptions to get theoretical guarantees for coreset construction.

Communication-efficient coreset construction for VRLR

Now we show that under mild condition, we can construct a strong coreset for VRLR using o‚Äã(n)ùëúùëõo(n) number of communication. Specifically, we assume the data ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} satisfies the following assumption, which will be justified in the appendix.

Assumption 4.1.

Let ùêî(j)‚àà‚Ñùn√ódj‚Ä≤superscriptùêîùëósuperscript‚Ñùùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëó{\bm{U}}^{(j)}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d^{\prime}_{j}} denote the orthonormal basis of the column space of ùêó(j)superscriptùêóùëó{\bm{X}}^{(j)} stored on party jùëój (ùêî(T)superscriptùêîùëá{\bm{U}}^{(T)} denotes the orthonormal basis of [ùêó(T),y]superscriptùêóùëáùë¶[{\bm{X}}^{(T)},y]), and then the matrix ùêî=[ùêî(1),ùêî(2),‚Ä¶,ùêî(T)]ùêîsuperscriptùêî1superscriptùêî2‚Ä¶superscriptùêîùëá{\bm{U}}=[{\bm{U}}^{(1)},{\bm{U}}^{(2)},\dots,{\bm{U}}^{(T)}] has smallest singular value œÉmin‚Äã(ùêî)‚â•Œ≥>0subscriptùúéùêîùõæ0\sigma_{\min}({\bm{U}})\geq\gamma>0.

Intuitively, Œ≥‚àà(0,1]ùõæ01\gamma\in(0,1] represents the degree of orthonormal among data in different parties. As the larger Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is, the more orthonormal among the column spaces of X(j)superscriptùëãùëóX^{(j)}, and thus UùëàU is more close to the orthonormal basis computed on XùëãX directly. Now we introduce our coreset construction algorithm for VRLR (Algorithm 2). At a very high level perspective, we let each party jùëój to compute a coreset S(j)superscriptùëÜùëóS^{(j)} based on its own data ùëø(j)superscriptùëøùëó{\bm{X}}^{(j)}, and combine all the S(j)superscriptùëÜùëóS^{(j)} together to obtain a final coreset SùëÜS. More specifically, for each party jùëój, we let it to compute ùëº(j)=[ùíñ1(j),‚Ä¶,ùíñn(j)]‚ä§superscriptùëºùëósuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùíñ1ùëó‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùíñùëõùëótop{\bm{U}}^{(j)}=[{\bm{u}}_{1}^{(j)},\dots,{\bm{u}}_{n}^{(j)}]^{\top} based on the data ùëø(j)superscriptùëøùëó{\bm{X}}^{(j)}, and set gi(j)=‚Äñùíñi(j)‚Äñ2+1nsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëósuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptùíñùëóùëñ21ùëõg_{i}^{(j)}=\|{\bm{u}}^{(j)}_{i}\|^{2}+\frac{1}{n} to be the weight of data iùëñi on party jùëój. Then, we set gi=‚àëj‚àà[T]gi(j)subscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}=\sum_{j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)} to be the final weight of data ùíôisubscriptùíôùëñ{\bm{x}}_{i} and want to sample mùëöm samples using weight gisubscriptùëîùëñg_{i}. To do this, we apply the DIS procedure (Algorithm 1).

Theorem 4.2 (Coresets for VRLR).

For a given dataset ùêó‚äÇ‚Ñùdùêósuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfying Assumption¬†4.1, number of parties T‚â•1ùëá1T\geq 1 and constants Œµ,Œ¥‚àà(0,1)ùúÄùõø01{\varepsilon},\delta\in(0,1), with probability at least 1‚àíŒ¥1ùõø1-\delta, Algorithm 2 constructs an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for VRLR of size m=O‚Äã(Œµ‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí2‚Äãd‚Äã(d2‚Äãlog‚Å°Œ≥‚àí2‚Äãd+log‚Å°1/Œ¥))ùëöùëÇsuperscriptùúÄ2superscriptùõæ2ùëësuperscriptùëë2superscriptùõæ2ùëë1ùõøm=O({\varepsilon}^{-2}\gamma^{-2}d(d^{2}\log{\gamma^{-2}d}+\log{1/\delta})), and uses communication complexity O‚Äã(m‚ÄãT)ùëÇùëöùëáO(mT).

Note that the coreset size and the total communication are all independent on nùëõn, and thus when combined with Theorem 2.5, using coreset construction can reduce the communication complexity for VRLR. When Assumption 4.1 is not satisfied, Algorithm 4.2 is not guaranteed to return a strong coreset. However, as shown in the following remark, it will return another kind of coreset called robust coreset ¬†[22, 32, 69], which allows a small portion of data to be treated as outliers and excluded both in SùëÜS and ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} when evaluating the quality of SùëÜS. The outliers represent a small percentage of data with unbounded sensitivity gap. More details can be found in the Theorem¬†G.3.

Remark 4.3 (Robust coreset for VRLR).

Given a dataset ùêó‚äÇ‚Ñùdùêósuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} together with labels ùê≤‚àà‚Ñùnùê≤superscript‚Ñùùëõ{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}, Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1) and Œ≤‚àà[0,1)ùõΩ01\beta\in[0,1), a subset S‚äÜ[n]ùëÜdelimited-[]ùëõS\subseteq[n] together with a weight function w:S‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùë§‚ÜíùëÜsubscript‚Ñùabsent0w:S\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} is called a (Œ≤,Œµ)ùõΩùúÄ(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset for offline regularized linear regression if for any ùõâ‚àà‚Ñùdùõâsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{\theta}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, there exists a subset Oùõâ‚äÜ[n]subscriptùëÇùõâdelimited-[]ùëõO_{{\bm{\theta}}}\subseteq[n] such that |Oùõâ|/n‚â§Œ≤subscriptùëÇùõâùëõùõΩ|O_{{\bm{\theta}}}|/n\leq\beta, |S‚à©Oùõâ|/|S|‚â§Œ≤ùëÜsubscriptùëÇùõâùëÜùõΩ|S\cap O_{{\bm{\theta}}}|/|S|\leq\beta and

ùñºùóàùóåùóçR‚Äã(S\OùúΩ,ùúΩ)‚ààùñºùóàùóåùóçR‚Äã(ùëø\OùúΩ,ùúΩ)¬±Œµ‚ãÖùñºùóàùóåùóçR‚Äã(ùëø,ùúΩ).superscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùëÖ\ùëÜsubscriptùëÇùúΩùúΩplus-or-minussuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùëÖ\ùëøsubscriptùëÇùúΩùúΩ‚ãÖùúÄsuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùëÖùëøùúΩ\mathsf{cost}^{R}(S\backslash O_{{\bm{\theta}}},{\bm{\theta}})\in\mathsf{cost}^{R}({\bm{X}}\backslash O_{{\bm{\theta}}},{\bm{\theta}})\pm{\varepsilon}\cdot\mathsf{cost}^{R}({\bm{X}},{\bm{\theta}}).

If Assumption 4.1 is not satisfied, for m=O‚Äã((Œµ‚ÄãŒ≤‚ÄãT)‚àí2‚Äãd6)ùëöùëÇsuperscriptùúÄùõΩùëá2superscriptùëë6m=O(({\varepsilon}\beta T)^{-2}d^{6}), Algorithm 2 will return a (Œ≤,Œµ)ùõΩùúÄ(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset for VRLR with communication complexity O‚Äã(m‚ÄãT)ùëÇùëöùëáO(mT).

5 Coreset Construction for VKMC

In this section, we discuss the coreset construction for VKMC. Similar to VRLR, we first show it generally requires Œ©‚Äã(n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(n) communication complexity to construct a coreset for VKMC, and then we show that it is possible to vastly reduce the communication complexity (Algorithm¬†3) under mild data assumption. All missing proofs can be found in Section¬†F.

Communication complexity lower bound for VKMC.

We first present an Œ©‚Äã(n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(n) communication complexity lower bound for constructing an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for VKMC in the following theorem.

Theorem 5.1 (Communication complexity of coreset construction for VKMC).

Let d‚â•T‚â•2ùëëùëá2d\geq T\geq 2. Given a constant Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1) and an integer k‚â•3ùëò3k\geq 3, any randomized communication scheme that constructs an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for VKMC with probability 0.99 requires a communication complexity Œ©‚Äã(n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(n).

Different from VRLR, we have a randomized communication complexity lower bound for VKMC. Similarly, we also need to introduce certain data assumptions to get theoretical guarantees for coreset construction due to this hardness result.

Communication-efficient coreset construction for VKMC

Now we show how to communication-efficiently construct coresets for VKMC under mild condition. Specifically, we assume that the data satisfies the following assumption, which will be justified in the appendix.

Assumption 5.1.

There exists œÑ‚â•1ùúè1\tau\geq 1 and some party t‚àà[T]ùë°delimited-[]ùëát\in[T] such that ‚Äñùê±i‚àíùê±j‚Äñ2‚â§œÑ‚Äã‚Äñùê±i(t)‚àíùê±j(t)‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùê±ùëñsubscriptùê±ùëó2ùúèsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptùê±ùë°ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê±ùë°ùëó2\left\|{\bm{x}}_{i}-{\bm{x}}_{j}\right\|^{2}\leq\tau\left\|{\bm{x}}^{(t)}_{i}-{\bm{x}}^{(t)}_{j}\right\|^{2} for any i,j‚àà[n]ùëñùëódelimited-[]ùëõi,j\in[n].

This assumption says that, there is a party that is ‚Äúimportant‚Äù, and any two data points which can be differentiated can also be differentiated on that party to some extent. Specifically, as œÑùúè\tau is more close to 1, Assumption 5.1 implies that there exists a party t‚àà[T]ùë°delimited-[]ùëát\in[T] whose local pairwise distances ‚Äñxi(t)‚àíxj(t)‚Äñnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùë°\|x_{i}^{(t)}-x_{j}^{(t)}\|s are close to the corresponding global pairwise distances ‚Äñxi‚àíxj‚Äñnormsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëó\|x_{i}-x_{j}\|s. Then we introduce our coreset construction algorithm for VKMC (Algorithm¬†3). For the input, note that there exist several constant approximation algorithms for kùëòk-means¬† [41, 66]. The widely used kùëòk-means++ algorithm [66] provides an O‚Äã(ln‚Å°k)ùëÇùëòO(\ln{k})-approximation and performs well in practice. Similar to Algorithm¬†2 for VRLR, Algorithm¬†3 also applies Algorithm¬†1 after computing gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)} locally. The key is to construct local sensitivities gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)} to upper bound both Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta and ùí¢ùí¢{\mathcal{G}} in Theorem¬†3.1. The derivation of the local sensitivities gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)} defined in Line 10 is partly inspired by [65], which upper bounds the total sensitivity of a point set in clustering problems by projecting points onto an optimal solution. Intuitively, if some party tùë°t satisfies Assumption¬†5.1, a constant factor approximate solution computed locally in party tùë°t can also induce a global one. Then by projecting points onto this global constant approximation, we can prove that gi(t)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùë°g_{i}^{(t)} (scaled by some constant factor) is an upper bound of the global sensitivity of ùíôisubscriptùíôùëñ{\bm{x}}_{i} for any i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n]. Though unaware of which party satisfies Assumption¬†5.1, it suffices to sum up gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)} over j‚àà[T]ùëódelimited-[]ùëáj\in[T], only costing an additional TùëáT in ùí¢ùí¢{\mathcal{G}}. Finally, we can upper bound Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta by O‚Äã(œÑ)ùëÇùúèO(\tau) and ùí¢ùí¢{\mathcal{G}} by O‚Äã(k‚ÄãT)ùëÇùëòùëáO(kT) respectively. The main theorem is as follows.

Theorem 5.2 (Coresets for VKMC).

For a given dataset ùêó‚äÇ‚Ñùdùêósuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfying Assumption¬†5.1, an Œ±ùõº\alpha-approximation algorithm for kùëòk-means¬†with Œ±=O‚Äã(1)ùõºùëÇ1\alpha=O(1), integers k‚â•1ùëò1k\geq 1, T‚â•1ùëá1T\geq 1 and constants Œµ,Œ¥‚àà(0,1)ùúÄùõø01{\varepsilon},\delta\in(0,1), with probability at least 1‚àíŒ¥1ùõø1-\delta, Algorithm 3 constructs an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset for VKMC of size m=O‚Äã(Œµ‚àí2‚ÄãŒ±‚ÄãœÑ‚Äãk‚ÄãT‚Äã(d‚Äãk‚Äãlog‚Å°(Œ±‚ÄãœÑ‚Äãk‚ÄãT)+log‚Å°1/Œ¥))ùëöùëÇsuperscriptùúÄ2ùõºùúèùëòùëáùëëùëòùõºùúèùëòùëá1ùõøm=O({\varepsilon}^{-2}\alpha\tau kT(dk\log{(\alpha\tau kT)}+\log{1/\delta})), and uses communication complexity O‚Äã(m‚ÄãT)ùëÇùëöùëáO(mT).

Again, note that both the coreset size and communication complexity are independent of nùëõn. Thus, using Algorithm 3 together with other baseline algorithms can drastically reduce the communication complexity. Similar to VRLR, we have the following remark when the data assumption (Assumption 5.1) is not satisfied. More details can be found in the Theorem G.4.

Remark 5.3 (Robust coreset for VKMC).

Given a dataset ùêó‚äÇ‚Ñùdùêósuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, an integer k‚â•1ùëò1k\geq 1, Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1) and Œ≤‚àà[0,1)ùõΩ01\beta\in[0,1), a subset S‚äÜ[n]ùëÜdelimited-[]ùëõS\subseteq[n] together with a weight function w:S‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùë§‚ÜíùëÜsubscript‚Ñùabsent0w:S\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} is called a (Œ≤,Œµ)ùõΩùúÄ(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset for offline kùëòk-means¬†clustering if for any ùêÇ‚äÇ‚ÑùdùêÇsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{C}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, there exists a subset OùêÇ‚äÜ[n]subscriptùëÇùêÇdelimited-[]ùëõO_{{\bm{C}}}\subseteq[n] such that |OùêÇ|/n‚â§Œ≤subscriptùëÇùêÇùëõùõΩ|O_{{\bm{C}}}|/n\leq\beta, |S‚à©OùêÇ|/|S|‚â§Œ≤ùëÜsubscriptùëÇùêÇùëÜùõΩ|S\cap O_{{\bm{C}}}|/|S|\leq\beta and

ùñºùóàùóåùóçC‚Äã(S\Oùë™,ùë™)‚ààùñºùóàùóåùóçC‚Äã(ùëø\Oùë™,ùë™)¬±Œµ‚ãÖùñºùóàùóåùóçC‚Äã(ùëø,ùë™).superscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùê∂\ùëÜsubscriptùëÇùë™ùë™plus-or-minussuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùê∂\ùëøsubscriptùëÇùë™ùë™‚ãÖùúÄsuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùê∂ùëøùë™\mathsf{cost}^{C}(S\backslash O_{{\bm{C}}},{\bm{C}})\in\mathsf{cost}^{C}({\bm{X}}\backslash O_{{\bm{C}}},{\bm{C}})\pm{\varepsilon}\cdot\mathsf{cost}^{C}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}}).

If Assumption 5.1 is not satisfied, for m=O‚Äã((Œµ‚ÄãŒ≤)‚àí2‚Äãk5‚Äãd)ùëöùëÇsuperscriptùúÄùõΩ2superscriptùëò5ùëëm=O(({\varepsilon}\beta)^{-2}k^{5}d) Algorithm 3 will return a (Œ≤,Œµ)ùõΩùúÄ(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset for VKMC with communication complexity O‚Äã(m‚ÄãT)ùëÇùëöùëáO(mT).

6 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we present the numerical experiments, which corroborate our theoretical results. We conduct experiments on a single system that simulates the distributed settings.222The codes are available at https://github.com/haoyuzhao123/coreset-vfl-codes.

Empirical setup.

We conduct experiments on the YearPredictionMSD dataset¬†[4] for both VRLR and VKMC. YearPredictionMSD dataset has 515345 data, and each data contains 90 features and a corresponding label. We assume there are T=3ùëá3T=3 parties and each party stories 30 distinct features. For VRLR, we split the data into a training set with size 463715 and a testing set with size 51630. We consider ridge regression in VRLR by letting R‚Äã(ùúΩ)=Œª‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩ‚Äñ2ùëÖùúΩùúÜsuperscriptnormùúΩ2R({\bm{\theta}})=\lambda\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|^{2} for Œª=0.1‚ÄãnùúÜ0.1ùëõ\lambda=0.1n where nùëõn is the dataset size. For VKMC, there is only one training set with size 515345 and without labels. We choose k=10ùëò10k=10 (10 centers) and we normalize each feature with mean 0 and standard deviation 1 for VKMC.

For VRLR, we consider two baselines: 1) Central as the procedure that transfers all data to the central server and solves the problem using scikit-learn package¬†[57]; 2) SAGA as using [18]‚Äôs algorithm to optimize in a VFL fashion. For VKMC, we also consider two baselines: 1) Kmeans++ as the procedure that transfers all data to the central server and clusters using Kmeans++¬†[66]; 2) DistDim by [19].

For each baseline, we compare our coreset algorithm with uniform sampling. We use C-X to denote coreset sampling followed by algorithm X and U-X for uniform sampling followed by algorithm X, e.g. C-DistDim means that we apply coreset construction and then use DistDim algorithm. We compare C-X and U-X with different sizes, and each experiment is repeated 20 times.

Empirical results.

Figure 2 shows our results for VRLR and Figure 3 shows our results for VKMC. Table 1 summarize the results. For VRLR, since it is a supervised learning problem, we report the testing loss; for VKMC, it is an unsupervised learning task and the cost refers to the training loss on the full training data.

Coreset sampling performs close to the baseline with less communication.

From the results, we find that using our coreset can achieve a similar loss compared to the baseline, while the communication complexity is reduced drastically. Specifically by Table¬†1, our coreset algorithm C-Central can use less than 0.4% of training data (2000/463715) and achieve a 95.01/90.45‚âà1.0595.0190.451.0595.01/90.45\approx 1.05-approximate solution for VRLR compared to the baseline Central. Observe that a larger coreset size leads to a smaller cost and a larger communication complexity. From Figures 2 and 3 (left), using coresets can reduce 50-100x communication complexity compared with the original baselines.

Coreset performs better than uniform sampling under the same communication.

From Figures¬†2 and 3 (right), we observe that our coresets always achieve a better solution than uniform sampling under the same sample size. Table 1 also reflects this trend. Under the same sample size, the communication complexity by uniform sampling is slightly lower than that of coreset, since there is no need to transfer weights in uniform sampling. Thus, we also compare the performance of our coresets and uniform sampling under the same communication complexity. From Figures¬†2 and 3 (left), we find that for different baselines, our coreset algorithms still achieve better testing loss/training cost while using fewer or the same communication, compared to uniform sampling.

Coreset and uniform sampling may also make the problem feasible.

It is also interesting to observe that SAGA will not converge (or very slowly) on the original VRLR problem (Table¬†1), possibly because of the large dataset and the ill-conditioned optimization problem. However, by applying the coreset/uniform sampling, SAGA works for VRLR. This also indicates the effectiveness of our framework and the importance to reduce the dependency on nùëõn (the dataset size).

7 Conclusion and Future Directions

In this paper, we first consider coreset construction in the vertical federated learning setting. We propose a unified coreset framework for communication-efficient VFL, and apply the framework to two important learning tasks: regularized linear regression and kùëòk-means clustering. We verify the efficiency of our coreset algorithms both theoretically and empirically, which can drastically alleviate the communication complexity while still maintaining the solution quality.

Our work initializes the topic of introducing coresets to VFL, which leaves several future directions. Firstly, our VFL coreset size is still larger than that of offline coresets for both VRLR and VKMC, even under certain data assumptions. One direction is to further improve the coreset size. Another interesting direction is to extend coreset construction to other learning tasks in the VFL setting, e.g., logistic regression or gradient boosting trees.

Checklist

  1. 1.

    For all authors‚Ä¶

    1. (a)

      Do the main claims made in the abstract and introduction accurately reflect the paper‚Äôs contributions and scope? [Yes]

    2. (b)

      Did you describe the limitations of your work? [Yes] See Section¬†7.

    3. (c)

      Did you discuss any potential negative societal impacts of your work? [No]

    4. (d)

      Have you read the ethics review guidelines and ensured that your paper conforms to them? [Yes]

  2. 2.

    If you are including theoretical results‚Ä¶

    1. (a)

      Did you state the full set of assumptions of all theoretical results? [Yes] See Assumption¬†4.1 and Assumption¬†5.1, and we also provide justification of these data assumtions in Section¬†B.

    2. (b)

      Did you include complete proofs of all theoretical results? [Yes] All missing proofs can be found in the appendix.

  3. 3.

    If you ran experiments‚Ä¶

    1. (a)

      Did you include the code, data, and instructions needed to reproduce the main experimental results (either in the supplemental material or as a URL)? [Yes] See section 6 footnote.

    2. (b)

      Did you specify all the training details (e.g., data splits, hyperparameters, how they were chosen)? [Yes]

    3. (c)

      Did you report error bars (e.g., with respect to the random seed after running experiments multiple times)? [Yes]

    4. (d)

      Did you include the total amount of compute and the type of resources used (e.g., type of GPUs, internal cluster, or cloud provider)? [No] All experiments are done using a single computer

  4. 4.

    If you are using existing assets (e.g., code, data, models) or curating/releasing new assets‚Ä¶

    1. (a)

      If your work uses existing assets, did you cite the creators? [Yes] See the baseline algorithms mentioned in Section¬†6.

    2. (b)

      Did you mention the license of the assets? [N/A]

    3. (c)

      Did you include any new assets either in the supplemental material or as a URL? [Yes] We provided the code for our experiments.

    4. (d)

      Did you discuss whether and how consent was obtained from people whose data you‚Äôre using/curating? [N/A]

    5. (e)

      Did you discuss whether the data you are using/curating contains personally identifiable information or offensive content? [N/A]

  5. 5.

    If you used crowdsourcing or conducted research with human subjects‚Ä¶

    1. (a)

      Did you include the full text of instructions given to participants and screenshots, if applicable? [N/A]

    2. (b)

      Did you describe any potential participant risks, with links to Institutional Review Board (IRB) approvals, if applicable? [N/A]

    3. (c)

      Did you include the estimated hourly wage paid to participants and the total amount spent on participant compensation? [N/A]

Appendix

Appendix A Additional Experiments

In this section, we present some additional experiments. This section is organized as follow: in Section A.1, we conduct experiments using different number of parties (as opposed to three parties in Section 6); in Section A.2, we test our methods using other regularizer for VRLR, e.g., Lasso; in Section A.3, we test our methods in VKMC with different number of centers; and finally in Section A.4, we conduct experiments on another dataset (KC House Dataset¬†[35]).

A.1 Different number of parties

In this section, we test our algorithms using different number of parties. We choose to use five parties (T=5ùëá5T=5) in this section instead of three parties in Section 6.

Empirical setup

Most of the experimental setups are the same as those in Section 6, except that now we use 5 parties instead of 3 parties. There are 90 dimensions for a single data in YearPredictionMSD dataset, and we let each party hold 18 dimensions. Besides, changing the number of parties does not affect the performance of U-Central and U-SAGA (but the number of communication will change due to different number of parties), and we reuse the results from Section 6 and recalculate the number of communications.

Empirical results

Figure 4 and 5 summarize our results for VRLR and VKMC respectively. Note that all the observations in Section 6 hold for 5 parties.

A.2 Different regularizer for VRLR

In this part, we consider using different regularizers in VRLR.

Empirical setup

We consider three different regression problems: plain linear regression, Lasso regression, and elastic nets. In Section 6, we consider the Ridge regression (R‚Äã(ùúΩ)=0.1‚Äãn‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩ‚Äñ22ùëÖùúΩ0.1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptnormùúΩ22R({\bm{\theta}})=0.1n\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|_{2}^{2} where nùëõn is the dataset size), and in this part, linear regression denotes the optimization problem where R‚Äã(ùúΩ)=0ùëÖùúΩ0R({\bm{\theta}})=0, Lasso regression denotes the problem where R‚Äã(ùúΩ)=2‚Äãn‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩ‚Äñ1ùëÖùúΩ2ùëõsubscriptnormùúΩ1R({\bm{\theta}})=2n\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|_{1}, and elastic net denotes the problem where R‚Äã(ùúΩ)=2‚Äãn‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩ‚Äñ1+n‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩ‚Äñ22ùëÖùúΩ2ùëõsubscriptnormùúΩ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptnormùúΩ22R({\bm{\theta}})=2n\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|_{1}+n\left\|{\bm{\theta}}\right\|_{2}^{2}. All the experiments setup remains the same as Section 6, except the for Lasso regression and elastic nets, there is no SAGA solver and we only compare C-Central and U-Central with Central.

Empirical results

We plot the training loss instead of the testing loss since we are comparing different objective functions. Figure 6, 7, and 8 show the empirical results in this part. Note that all the observations in Section 6 also hold: (1) coreset sampling and uniform sampling can drastically reduce the communication complexity where nearly maintain the solution performance, and (2) coreset performs better than uniform sampling under the same number of communication.

A.3 Different number of centers for VKMC

In this section we test our methods on VKMC using different number of centers.

Empirical setup

The experimental setup in this part is the same as the setup in Section 6 for VKMC, except that we are using 5 centers instead of 10 centers.

Empirical results

Figure 9 summarizes the result. All the observations in Section 6 also hold.

A.4 Experiments on other datasets

In this section, we present the experiment results on another dataset. We choose the KC House Dataset¬†[35] for both VRLR and VKMC.

Empirical setup

Our experiment setup is nearly the same as the setup in Section 6. However, there are a few differences: (1) the dataset we use is KC House Dataset¬†[35], which contains 21613 data points and each datapoint constains 18 features and a label; (2) we conduct the experiment using only two parties because the limited number of features, we put the first nine features on the first party and the remaining on the second; and (3), we do not consider regularizer for VRLR (plain linear regression). Also note that similar to Section 6, we normalize each feature to have standard deviation 1 during the clustering task.

Empirical results

For VRLR, we plot the training loss instead of the testing loss, since the dataset is not so large and coreset does not have theoretical guarantee for generalization error. Figure 10 and 11 summarize our results for VRLR and VKMC respectively. From the results, we still find that our coreset construction method can outperform uniform sampling, and both of them can drastically reduce the communication complexity compared with the original baselines.

Note that in Figure 10, C-SAGA and U-SAGA performs much worse than the baseline Central. However, C-Central can perform much better and has similar performance as Central, and this phenomenon may attribute to the fact that this problem is hard to solve by SAGA algorithm, and using other second-order methods¬†[73] may help. Also note that when the size is small (100 and 200), U-Central may produce ‚Äúridiculous‚Äù solutions and the cost blows up.

Appendix B Justification of Data Assumptions

In this section, we justify our data assumptions in Section 4 (Assumption 4.1) and Section 5 (Assumption 5.1). We show that in the smoothed analysis regime, Assumption 4.1 and 5.1 are easy to satisfy with some standard assumptions. In Section B.1, we show the results related to Assumption 4.1, and in Section B.2, we justify Assumption 5.1.

B.1 Justification of Assumption 4.1

In this section, we interpret and justify Assumption 4.1. First, we recall Assumption 4.1.

See 4.1

Assumption 4.1 requires that the subspace generated by any party cannot be included in the subspace generated by all other parties. However, it it not sure what standard assumptions can lead to Assumption 4.1. The following lemma shows that, œÉmin‚Äã(ùëº)subscriptùúéùëº\sigma_{\min}({\bm{U}}) can be lower bounded by th smallest and largest singular value of matrix ùëø‚Ä≤=[ùëø,ùíö]superscriptùëø‚Ä≤ùëøùíö{\bm{X}}^{\prime}=[{\bm{X}},{\bm{y}}].

œÉmin‚Äã(ùëº)‚â•œÉmin‚Äã(ùëø‚Ä≤)œÉmax‚Äã(ùëø‚Ä≤).subscriptùúéùëºsubscriptùúésuperscriptùëø‚Ä≤subscriptùúésuperscriptùëø‚Ä≤\sigma_{\min}({\bm{U}})\geq\frac{\sigma_{\min}({\bm{X}}^{\prime})}{\sigma_{\max}({\bm{X}}^{\prime})}.

Using the preivous lemma, it is easy to analyze the smallest singular value œÉ‚Äã(ùëº)ùúéùëº\sigma({\bm{U}}) in the smoothed analysis regime. Specifically, we prove that for any dataset [ùëø,ùíö]ùëøùíö[{\bm{X}},{\bm{y}}] satisfying certain conditions, we add a random perturbation on the dataset, resulting [ùëøp,ùíöp]subscriptùëøùëùsubscriptùíöùëù[{\bm{X}}_{p},{\bm{y}}_{p}], and we show that with high probability, ùëºpsubscriptùëºùëù{\bm{U}}_{p} (which is constructed from dataset [ùëøp,ùíöp]subscriptùëøùëùsubscriptùíöùëù[{\bm{X}}_{p},{\bm{y}}_{p}] has smallest singular value. The result is formalized in the following theorem.

Theorem B.1.

Proposition B.1 (Smoothed analysis of condition number, Theorem 1.1 in [8]).

Suppose that ùêÄ¬Ø‚àà‚Ñùn√ód¬ØùêÄsuperscript‚Ñùùëõùëë\bar{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d} satisfies ‚ÄñùêÄ¬Ø‚Äñ‚â§1norm¬ØùêÄ1\left\|\bar{\bm{A}}\right\|\leq 1, and let 0<rp‚â§10subscriptùëüùëù10<r_{p}\leq 1. Then,

B.2 Justification of Assumption 5.1

In this section, we justify Assumption 5.1. We first recall the assumption.

See 5.1

Roughly speaking, this assumption requires there is a party that is ‚Äúimportant‚Äù, and any two data points which can be differentiated can also be differentiated on that party to some extent. In reality, this assumption should be approximately satisfied since different features should be ‚Äúcorrelated‚Äù.

Next, similar to the justification of Assumption 4.1, we use smoothed analysis framework to show that for dataset ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} under certain conditions, by perturbing the dataset for a little bit, Assumption 5.1 will be satisfied with high probability. Formally, we have the following theorem.

Theorem B.2.

For any dataset where each data point ‚Äñùê±i‚Äñ22‚â§Bsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùê±ùëñ22ùêµ\left\|{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq B for all ùê±i‚ààùêósubscriptùê±ùëñùêó{\bm{x}}_{i}\in{\bm{X}} and maxj‚àà[T]‚Å°dj‚â•Œ©‚Äã(log2‚Å°n)subscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëásubscriptùëëùëóŒ©superscript2ùëõ\max_{j\in[T]}d_{j}\geq\Omega(\log^{2}n). If we perturb the dataset by a small random Gaussian noise ùêópsubscriptùêóùëù{\bm{X}}_{p} where ùêóp=ùêó+ùêôsubscriptùêóùëùùêóùêô{\bm{X}}_{p}={\bm{X}}+{\bm{Z}}, and each coordinate of ùêôùêô{\bm{Z}} and ùê∞ùê∞{\bm{w}} comes from ùí©‚Äã(0,r2‚ÄãB2)ùí©0superscriptùëü2superscriptùêµ2{\mathcal{N}}(0,r^{2}B^{2}). Then with high probability, ùêópsubscriptùêóùëù{\bm{X}}_{p} satisfies Assumption 5.1 with

œÑ=O‚Äã(1r2+dlog2‚Å°n)ùúèùëÇ1superscriptùëü2ùëësuperscript2ùëõ\tau=O\left(\frac{1}{r^{2}}+\frac{d}{\log^{2}n}\right)

The intuition of the proof is that, the norm of a high-dimensional (sub-)gaussian random vector should concentrate around Œò‚Äã(d)Œòùëë\Theta(\sqrt{d}), where dùëëd is the dimension of the (sub-)gaussian random vector. Thus, as long as we add some perturbation to the original dataset, the norm of the difference between any two perturbed data points on party jùëój should be at least djsubscriptùëëùëó\sqrt{d_{j}}. Formally, we have the following proposition for the concentration of norm.

Proposition B.2 (Concentration of the norm).

Appendix C Proof of Theorem¬†2.5

Proof of Theorem¬†2.5.

We only take VRLR as an example. We consider the following communication scheme: First apply the communication scheme A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} to construct an ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset (S,w)ùëÜùë§(S,w) for VRLR in the server; then the server broadcasts (S,w)ùëÜùë§(S,w) to all parties; and finally apply the communication scheme Aùê¥A to (S,w)ùëÜùë§(S,w) and obtain a solution ùúΩ‚àà‚ÑùdùúΩsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{\theta}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} in the server.

Let ùúΩ‚ãÜsuperscriptùúΩ‚ãÜ{\bm{\theta}}^{\star} be the optimal solution for the offline regularized linear regression problem.

By the coreset definition, we have that

E.1 Communication lower bound for VRLR coreset construction

The proof is via a reduction from an EQUALITY problem to the problem of coreset construction for VRLR. For preparation, we first introduce some concepts in the field of communication complexity.

Communication complexity.

Here it suffices to consider the two-party case (T=2ùëá2T=2). Assume we have two players Alice and Bob, whose inputs are x‚ààùí≥ùë•ùí≥x\in{\mathcal{X}} and y‚ààùí¥ùë¶ùí¥y\in{\mathcal{Y}} respectively. For the input (x,y)ùë•ùë¶(x,y), the coordinator outputs Œ†‚Äã(x,y)Œ†ùë•ùë¶\Pi(x,y) when Alice and Bob run Œ†Œ†\Pi on it. We also use Œ†‚Äã(x,y)Œ†ùë•ùë¶\Pi(x,y) to denote the transcript (concatenation of messages). Let |Œ†x,y|subscriptŒ†ùë•ùë¶|\Pi_{x,y}| be the length of the transcript. The communication complexity of Œ†Œ†\Pi is defined as maxx,y‚Å°|Œ†x,y|subscriptùë•ùë¶subscriptŒ†ùë•ùë¶\max_{x,y}|\Pi_{x,y}|. The Œ¥ùõø\delta-error randomized communication complexity of fùëìf, denoted by RŒ¥‚Äã(f)subscriptùëÖùõøùëìR_{\delta}(f), is the minimum communication complexity of any protocol with error at most Œ¥ùõø\delta.

F.1 Communication lower bound for VKMC coreset construction

The proof is via a reduction from a set-disjointness (DISJ) problem to the problem of coreset construction for VKMC.

DISJ problem.

In the DISJ problem, Alice holds a={a1,‚Ä¶,an}‚àà{0,1}nùëésubscriptùëé1‚Ä¶subscriptùëéùëõsuperscript01ùëõa=\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}\}\in\{0,1\}^{n} and Bob holds b={b1,‚Ä¶,bn}‚àà{0,1}nùëèsubscriptùëè1‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùëõsuperscript01ùëõb=\{b_{1},\ldots,b_{n}\}\in\{0,1\}^{n}. The following lemma gives a well-known communication lower bound for DISJ.

Lemma F.1 (Communication complexity of DISJ¬†[37, 59, 3]).

The randomized communication complexity of DISJ is Œ©‚Äã(n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(n), i.e., for Œ¥‚àà[0,1/2)ùõø012\delta\in[0,1/2) and n‚â•1ùëõ1n\geq 1, RŒ¥‚Äã(DISJ)=Œ©‚Äã(n)subscriptùëÖùõøDISJŒ©ùëõR_{\delta}(\textrm{DISJ})=\Omega(n).

F.2 Proof of Theorem¬†5.2

Constructing local sensitivities.

Lemma F.2 (Upper bounding the global sensitivity of VKMC locally).

Given a dataset ùêó‚äÇ‚Ñùdùêósuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} with Assumption¬†5.1, an Œ±ùõº\alpha-approximation algorithm for kùëòk-means¬†with Œ±=O‚Äã(1)ùõºùëÇ1\alpha=O(1) and integers k‚â•1ùëò1k\geq 1, T‚â•1ùëá1T\geq 1, the local sensitivities gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)} in Algorithm¬†3 satisfies that for any i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n], supùêÇ‚ààùíûùñºùóàùóåùóçiC‚Äã(ùêó,ùêÇ)ùñºùóàùóåùóçC‚Äã(ùêó,ùêÇ)‚â§4‚ÄãœÑ‚Äã‚àëj‚àà[T]gi(j)subscriptsupremumùêÇùíûsubscriptsuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùê∂ùëñùêóùêÇsuperscriptùñºùóàùóåùóçùê∂ùêóùêÇ4ùúèsubscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëó\sup_{{\bm{C}}\in{\mathcal{C}}}\frac{\mathsf{cost}^{C}_{i}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}})}{\mathsf{cost}^{C}({\bm{X}},{\bm{C}})}\leq 4\tau\sum_{j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)}, i.e., Œ∂=O‚Äã(œÑ)ùúÅùëÇùúè\zeta=O(\tau). Moreover, ùí¢:=‚àëi‚àà[n],j‚àà[T]gi(j)=O‚Äã(Œ±‚Äãk‚ÄãT)assignùí¢subscriptformulae-sequenceùëñdelimited-[]ùëõùëódelimited-[]ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóùëÇùõºùëòùëá{\mathcal{G}}:=\sum_{i\in[n],j\in[T]}g_{i}^{(j)}=O(\alpha kT).

The proof can be found in Section¬†F.3, and it is partly modified from the dimension-reduction type argument [65], which upper bounds the total sensitivity of a point set in clustering problem by projecting points onto an optimal solution. Intuitively, if some party tùë°t satisfies Assumption¬†5.1, the partition over [n]delimited-[]ùëõ[n] corresponding to an Œ±ùõº\alpha-approximation computed using local data will induce a global Œ±‚ÄãœÑùõºùúè\alpha\tau-approximate solution. Hence, combining this with the argument mentioned above, we derive that gi(t)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùë°g_{i}^{(t)} (scaled by 4‚ÄãœÑ4ùúè4\tau) is an upper bound of the global sensitivity. Though unaware of which party satisfies Assumption¬†5.1, it suffices to sum up gi(j)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëóg_{i}^{(j)} over j‚àà[T]ùëódelimited-[]ùëáj\in[T], costing an addtional TùëáT in ùí¢ùí¢{\mathcal{G}}.

Proof of Theorem¬†5.2.

By Lemma¬†F.2, the sensitivity gap Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta is O‚Äã(œÑ)ùëÇùúèO(\tau) and the total sensitivity ùí¢ùí¢{\mathcal{G}} is O‚Äã(Œ±‚Äãk‚ÄãT)ùëÇùõºùëòùëáO(\alpha kT). Plugging them into Theorem¬†3.1 completes the proof. ‚àé

Appendix G Robust Coresets for VRLR and VKMC

In this section, we prove that even if the data assumptions¬†4.1 and¬†5.1 fail to hold, Algorithms¬†2 and¬†3 still provide robust coresets for VRLR (Theorem¬†G.3) and VKMC (Theorem¬†G.4) in the flavor of approximating with outliers.

G.1 Robust coreset

In this section, we introduce a general definition of robust coreset. For preparation, we first give some notations for a function space, which can be easily specialized to the cases for VRLR and VKMC. Given a dataset ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} of size nùëõn, let FùêπF be a set of cost functions from ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} to ‚Ñù‚â•0subscript‚Ñùabsent0\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}. For a subset S‚äÜ[n]ùëÜdelimited-[]ùëõS\subseteq[n] with a weight function w:S‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùë§‚ÜíùëÜsubscript‚Ñùabsent0w:S\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, we denote f‚Äã(S)ùëìùëÜf(S) to be the weighted total cost over SùëÜS for any f‚ààFùëìùêπf\in F, i.e., f‚Äã(S)=‚àëi‚ààSw‚Äã(i)‚Äãf‚Äã(ùíôi)ùëìùëÜsubscriptùëñùëÜùë§ùëñùëìsubscriptùíôùëñf(S)=\sum_{i\in S}w(i)f({\bm{x}}_{i}). With a slight abuse of notation, we can see ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} as [n]delimited-[]ùëõ[n] with unit weight such that f‚Äã(ùëø)=‚àëi‚àà[n]f‚Äã(ùíôi)ùëìùëøsubscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõùëìsubscriptùíôùëñf({\bm{X}})=\sum_{i\in[n]}f({\bm{x}}_{i}). Now we define the robust coreset as follows.

Definition G.1 (Robust coreset).

Let Œ≤‚àà[0,1)ùõΩ01\beta\in[0,1), and Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01{\varepsilon}\in(0,1). Given a set FùêπF of functions from ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} to ‚Ñù‚â•0subscript‚Ñùabsent0\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, we say that a weighted subset of S‚äÜ[n]ùëÜdelimited-[]ùëõS\subseteq[n] is a (Œ≤,Œµ)ùõΩùúÄ(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset of ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} if for any f‚ààFùëìùêπf\in F, there exists a subset Of‚äÜ[n]subscriptùëÇùëìdelimited-[]ùëõO_{f}\subseteq[n] such that

|Of|n‚â§Œ≤,|S‚à©Of||S|subscriptùëÇùëìùëõùõΩùëÜsubscriptùëÇùëìùëÜ\displaystyle\frac{|O_{f}|}{n}\leq\beta,\frac{|S\cap O_{f}|}{|S|} ‚â§Œ≤,absentùõΩ\displaystyle\leq\beta,
|f‚Äã(ùëø\Of)‚àíf‚Äã(S\Of)|ùëì\ùëøsubscriptùëÇùëìùëì\ùëÜsubscriptùëÇùëì\displaystyle\left|f({\bm{X}}\backslash O_{f})-f(S\backslash O_{f})\right| ‚â§Œµ‚Äãf‚Äã(ùëø).absentùúÄùëìùëø\displaystyle\leq{\varepsilon}f({\bm{X}}).

Roughly speaking, we allow a small portion of data to be treated as outliers and neglected both in ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} and SùëÜS when considering the quality of SùëÜS. Note that a (0,Œµ)0ùúÄ(0,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset is equivalent to a standard ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}-coreset, and SùëÜS provides a slightly weaker approximation guarantee with additive error if Œ≤>0ùõΩ0\beta>0. Also note that our definition of robust coreset is a bit different from that in previous work¬†[22, 32, 69], which focus on generating robust coresets from uniform sampling, but basically they all capture similar ideas. This is because we will be interested in the robustness of importance sampling under the case where a small percentage of data have unbounded sensitivity gap in Algorithm¬†1, and the above definition gives simpler results.

We propose the following theorem to show that (S,w)ùëÜùë§(S,w) returned by Algorithm¬†1 is a (Œ≤,Œµ)ùõΩùúÄ(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset when size mùëöm is large enough.

The proof is in Section¬†G.4. Recall that the term sigisubscriptùë†ùëñsubscriptùëîùëñ\frac{s_{i}}{g_{i}} represents the sensitivity gap of point ùíôisubscriptùíôùëñ{\bm{x}}_{i}, and Algorithm¬†1 guarantees sublinear communication complexity only if the maximum sensitivity gap Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta over all points is independent of nùëõn. The main idea in the above theorem is that we can reduce the portion of potential outliers (with large sensitivity gap) to a small constant both in ùëøùëø{\bm{X}} and SùëÜS via scaling sample size mùëöm by a sufficiently large constant.

Theorem G.3 (Robust coresets for VRLR).

For a given dataset ùêó‚äÇ‚Ñùdùêósuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bm{X}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, integer T‚â•1ùëá1T\geq 1 and constants Œ≤,Œµ,Œ¥‚àà(0,1)ùõΩùúÄùõø01\beta,{\varepsilon},\delta\in(0,1), with probability at least 1‚àíŒ¥1ùõø1-\delta, Algorithm¬†2 constructs a (Œ≤,Œµ)ùõΩùúÄ(\beta,{\varepsilon})-robust coreset for VRLR of size

m=O‚Äã(d4Œµ2‚ÄãŒ≤2‚ÄãT2‚Äã(d2+log‚Å°1Œ¥)),ùëöùëÇsuperscriptùëë4superscriptùúÄ2superscriptùõΩ2superscriptùëá2superscriptùëë21ùõøm=O\left(\frac{d^{4}}{{\varepsilon}^{2}\beta^{2}T^{2}}\left(d^{2}+\log{\frac{1}{\delta}}\right)\right),

G.3 Robust coresets for VKMC

The following theorem shows that Algorithm¬†3 returns a robust coreset for VKMC when sample size mùëöm is large enough. Note that mùëöm is still independent of nùëõn.
